thread.title: Galaxy's defense disappears at home in loss to Portland, jeopardizing its playoff position
thread.title_full: Galaxy's defense disappears at home in loss to Portland, jeopardizing its playoff position - The Orange County Register

title: Galaxy's defense disappears at home in loss to Portland, jeopardizing its playoff position
text:
CARSON – Of all the games for its defense to fall apart at home, the Galaxy probably picked the worst moment.
With playoff positioning at stake in the final home game of the regular season, the Galaxy, which had lost just once at home all season, got buried under a barrage of goals from Portland, falling 5-2 at StubHub Center.
The Timbers (14-11-8) scored five goals in a 26-minute span in the second half to send the Galaxy (14-10-9) spiraling to defeat in front of a crowd of 27,000.
“They (Portland) dominated us in the second half and deserved to win the game,” Galaxy coach Bruce Arena said. “You look at individual battles, their 11 against our 11, they just thoroughly dominated us in a physical nature, I would say, more than anything.”

With a victory, the Galaxy, which has already clinched a playoff berth, could have jumped to 54 points and sealed the second seed in the Western Conference, earning a first-round bye.
Now, with one regular-season game remaining (Sunday at Sporting Kansas City), the Galaxy could conceivably find itself in the one-game, knockout playoff, which pits the third seed of the respective conferences against the sixth and the fourth against the fifth.
Heading into the final week, the Galaxy, with 51 points, has a one-point lead over Vancouver and Portland. Seattle and Sporting Kansas City have 48.
Robbie Keane opened the scoring in the 36th minute for the Galaxy. Fanendo Adi (65th and 68th) gave the Timbers the lead, 2-1. Diego Chara followed with a free header in the 74th minute.
The Galaxy thought it had some life in the 84th minute when Keane scored again, cutting the lead to 3-2, but approximately 20 seconds from kickoff, Portland’s Darlington Nagbe beat his defender and Galaxy goalkeeper Donovan Ricketts for a 4-2 lead.
“To a man, it wasn’t good enough,” Galaxy midfielder Steven Gerrard said. “We have to take responsibility for that second-half performance.”
The last time the Galaxy allowed five goals at home was in 2009, in a 6-3 loss to FC Dallas.
Now, it has to find a way to get the necessary result on the road. The club has just two victories on the road this season.
“This was obviously a disappointment in the last home game of the season,” Keane said. “It was embarrassing, the manner we conceded the goals.
“This stage of the season, we can’t feel sorry for ourselves, it is disappointing now, but it is important to move on quickly as possible. We can’t dwell too much on this.”
Contact the writer: dcalhoun@ocregister.com
